channel.title: Building a Computer
channel.description:
I am building a new computer, from www.gamedude.com.au. These are the parts a friend has chosen, I was wondering if anybody else thinks otherwise. It should be fine, but I want the system to be as good as I can get. I am looking to build a gaming/media system.
(Please note that all prices are $AUD)
The parts I have picked out:
$50 - Speakers: OMNI MA691 5.1 Channel Multimedia Speaker System PMPO 3500watt $175- Case: XG EXTREME GAMER VIPER BLACK / BLUE 500watt with Window $45(X2) - Burner: ASUS 16x BLACK DVD +/- R, Model DRW-1608P3S 5x DVD RAM $139 - Hard drive: SeaGate 320 gig 7200rpm SATA-2 NCQ 16meg Cache 7200.10 $60 - Hard Drive: SeaGate 80 gig 7200rpm SATA-2 7200.10 ST380815AS NCQ 8meg Cache $119 (X2) - 1 gig DDR2 533Mhz (PC2-4200) SO-DIMM TOP QUALITY VARIOUS BRANDS $269- Screen: 19inch CMV Chimei TFT WIDE SCREEN WXGA 1440x900 DVI Cable Speakers 5ms Response Model: V938D $199- Motherboard: MSI G965MDH-FI Intel® G965 Chipset 6 SATAII ports DDR2 SDRAM AUDIO LAN IEEE1394 CORE 2 SUPPORTED $329- CPU: INTEL CORE 2 DUO E6400 2.13Ghz 2m CACHE 1066FSB LGA 775 $55- Floppy: Floppy with Card Reader BLACK SOHOUSB MODEL : HFR-215N3 USB 2.0 15 different media formats $500- Video Card: Asus GF 8800 gts 320mb $85- Keyboard: LOGITECH G11 Gaming Keyboard $79- Mouse: LOGITECH G5 Laser Mouse USB Retail Box $35- Sound Card: CREATIVE Sound Blaster 5.1 PCI
Total: $2,430
About the two different sized hard drives, I am planning on installing everything on the smaller one, and putting all my music, files and movies on the other. That way, I can format to get rid of all the crap and keep the speed up, but not spend hours backing up.
I know this would take time, but if somebody went over the parts and would recommend something better if they think it is I would really appreciate it.

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

My grandparents live in the US, but the cost of postage and the waiting doesn’t really make it worth bothering. I will probably end up saving 20 bucks and waiting 2 weeks.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

^^ I changed the case to a viper. It costs more, but has a better psu and fans. I wanted a gaming case for the temperature display, plenty of upgrade room and the fans on the case. The graphics card that I picked out runs hot and i need sufficent cooling.

@Mopar: That looks like a better place to buy my parts, but I can’t get it shipped to Australia.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

If your paying 150 for a case, it better be good. I paid $30 for mine (with a 25 dollar rebate) and it is just as good as ones going for 100. You could also look for either barebone kits or a mobo and dual core bundle. I say go for AMD though, because I don’t like pentiums.
I would recommend Tigerdirect.com if they ship to your area.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

On another topic

Oh really? I thought they shipped to all of North America.

Newegg.com does not currently ship internationally; we only deliver to locations within the United States and to Puerto Rico.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

The problem with newegg is that they only ship to America. I would love to buy from them, but they won’t even ship to Canada.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Original Daniel:

$329- CPU: INTEL CORE 2 DUO E6400 2.13Ghz 2m CACHE 1066FSB LGA 775

The rest of your prices are quite high, but that one is insane. I paid:

google.com:

200 U.S. dollars = 258.46472 Australian dollars

for the same processor about 4 months ago.

newegg.com

Intel Core 2 Duo E6400 Conroe Dual-Core 2.13 GHz LGA 775 65W BX80557E6400...

Buy Intel Core 2 Duo E6400 Conroe Dual-Core 2.13 GHz LGA 775 65W BX80557E6400 Processor with fast shipping and top-rated customer service.Once you know, you Newegg!

It is a little more expensive now, but buy from newegg.com if you can, they rule.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

DON’T GET NVIDIA. GET ATI RADEON. Get one of the RXXX’s series, like the 9800 Pro

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

^^ Yeh thats the card I am getting now, just forgot to update the list.

About the expensive motherboard, I was thinking about that, but I don’t know too much about motherboards and didn’t want to get a crap one.

Could anybody please tell me the differences between
mbASconroexfire - on the gamedude site search that under item code.($199)
and mbMSg965mdh_fi ($135)

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @juju juju
item.description:
@juju wrote:

You should get the INNO3D NVIDIA 8800 GTS 320MB 320Bit GDDR3 Core Frequency 500/1600Mhz SLi Ready imo.

It’s only $150 more but offers much better graphics then the 7900GS, also, the 8800 series supports DirectX 10.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

double is a rule of thumb its really around 3/4 of the value

Read full topic

Thanks frank_ I had a look and picked out the Asus GF 8800 gts 320mb
I have to wait another week or so before I can afford it.

http://www.umart.com.au/newindex2.phtml?bid=5

Do you live around that area too?

Whatta…


?

item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:

iamafisher:

7900 GTX

LIES.

They have already released one wave of cheap dx10 cards, the next wave will come in a couple of months.

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

^^ I have heard that duel core isn’t that great, I am still getting a fan (only just remembered it) and overclocking.

jcs_double:

one question why buy 2 hard disks you can buy one larger hard disk and put one OS partition and one for everything else or however you like or buy 2 the same and have a RAID 0 config

My friend tried a partition and had problems with it. How does raid 0 work? All the different types confuse me

EDIT: I read some reviews and that graphics card doesn’t look too great, Could somebody make some suggestions? (from gamedude) I don’t want to spend much over $400AUD for it.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

Drop the core2 duo and get a Pentium 4 Dual core + water cooling and overclock it. It will do you MUCH better. Thats what I’m running (4.1 Ghz FTW!)

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @jcs_double jcs_double
item.description:
@jcs_double wrote:

one question why buy 2 hard disks you can buy one larger hard disk and put one OS partition and one for everything else or however you like or buy 2 the same and have a RAID 0 config
